text: Yeah, so the class is really going to be about the Book of Jubilees, which is a piece of Second Temple Jewish literature. It's one of the most important ones, probably the first one people think of, maybe the Book of Enoch or 1st Enoch. But Jubilees has had an ongoing relevance. It's a little more sub rosa. You don't find people debating it as openly or that kind of thing. You're not going to find as many patristic quotes of people talking about the Book of Enoch and who wrote it and that kind of thing. But Jubilees is the very rare Second Temple Jewish text that you'll still find, for example, linked on Jewish websites, even Rabbinic Judaism, although they have a kind of weird relationship with it, but it has kind of lingered around and it has an afterlife into the medieval period in terms of elements of it. So that makes it in particular kind of important. And it does deal with the origins of the Nephilim and people get excited when I talk about giants. So we went ahead and put that in the title to remind people that that's going to be.

episode_id: SW - #404 - 2025-08-19 - Fr. Stephen De Young - How to Read Extra-Biblical Texts Like Jubilees (and Why It Matters)

text: So get excited. But so it's going to be about the text. And what, what Jubilees really is is it's sort of an expanded retelling of the Book of Genesis and the first part of the Book of Exodus. So it's framed as. Here is the vision that Moses had and the experience that Moses has when he's on Mount Sinai for the 40 days from which he is going to compose Genesis and the part of Exodus leading up to him being there. So it includes, you know, the basic framework of the biblical stories of Genesis, but then also includes sort of expanded details, even whole other story elements and narrative elements that aren't there in the received text of Genesis. So that's, that's really what it is. That's what we're going to be covering. We're going to be discussing not just the traditions surrounding the Nephilim, but those. And then also these other traditions surrounding the patriarchal narratives about Abraham, Isaac and Jacob and Joseph creation, the Fall all of those things.
